resources.string: What do you want to save per week?

I developed this app to make sure I wasn't spending too much of my pay check in my post-college career (and to help me manage repaying my student loans). I put it on the app store in hopes that someone else may find it as useful as I do. 
 
 Here are explanations by menu. 
 
 Home Screen Menu
 I Spent Money: Out of pocket expenses.
 Add Money: Adds money to your balance (whenever you get money randomly).
 Edit Information: Specify your income, bills, savings, and categories of things you spend money on.
 Statictics: View allowance, spending habits, due dates of bills, and your expenses history.
 
 
 Edit Information Menu
 Edit My Income: What you make (after taxes).
 Edit Bills: Specify your bills, what they cost, on what time intervals, and when they're due.
 Edit Spending Categories: Specify what you spend money on. (groceries, eating out, gas, car maintenance, misc.).
 Edit Savings: Specify what you want to save each week.
 
 
 Statistics
 Spending History: Your expenses (and additions) to your balance.
 Spending Habits: Shows you in percentages what you spend money on (based on your specified categories).
 Bill Due Dates: Lists your bills in the order they are due.
 Daily Allowance: Shows you how much you can spend each day.
 
 
 Example Use
 Let's say you're salaried at $40,000 a year and paid bi-weekly. Your bi-weekly pay check is $1230 after taxes. Multiply that by 26 (number of bi-weeks in a year) and you net ~$32,000.
 
 So an example would look like this.
 ANNUAL INCOME: 32000
 
 REPEATING EXPENSES: Rent|500 per month, Student Loans|500 per month, Cell Phone|60 per month, Cable/Internet|80 per month, Car Insurance|400 per bi-year, Electric|80 per month
 
 SAVINGS: $100 per week 
 
 EXPENSE CATEGORIES: Groceries, Gas, Eating Out, Clothes, Fun Purchases, Car Maintenance, Exercise Equipment, Miscellaneous
 
 So your bills are $15,440 per year, you save $5,200 per year, and you can spend $11,360 (~$31 per day) on everything else (in Expense Categories).
 
 So if over the course of two weeks you spend $80 on gas, $120 eating out, $80 on groceries, and buy a $30 gift for someone, your balance will be $125 at the end of 2 weeks.
